head.supplied: Melbourne botanic Garden, ¶ 30. May 1863 ¶ Sir ¶ ¶ In reply to your circular N. 1895 ¶ I have the honor to inform you, that no alteration has taken place in the number of my securities ¶ for the Go...

div.p: A63/3453, unit 749, VPRS 1189/P inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.

In reply to your circular N. 1895
Circular not found. I have the honor to inform you, that no alteration has taken place in the number of my securities
is the subject securities or sureties?
for the Government, but that Captain Andrew Clarke has left this country. If the adopted regulations render it necessary to substitute for the name of that Gentleman one who is resident in Victoria, I shall not fail to do so, whenever your intimation on this subject will reach me.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p: I have the honor to be,

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p:
The honorable the Chief Secretary.
On 4 June 1863 the Under Secretary, J. Moore, referred M's letter to the Treasurer for his opinion. The Under Treasurer, E. Symonds, replied on 16 June: 'Dr Mueller originally gave three sureties As Drs Howitt and Wilkie are still in the colony and Capt Clarke in receipt of a pension from it, there appears to be no reason to disturb existing arrangements'.
